attributes.title: Stock Verification
attributes.description: Physical stock counted compared to SAP inventory warehouse balances revealed variances as follows; Bread had -18.50 loaves, Yeast had -2 sachets, Utto had +1.783 Litres, Wheat bran had -4.35kg, while Polybags had +975 pieces. The rest of the stock items had minimal or zero variances.
attributes.recommendation:
•    Stock controls in place should be maintained to safeguard all stock items.
•    Excess variance in polybags should be investigated to establish the root cause.
attributes.effect: Minimal stock variations is indication of adequate controls in place, investigation on polybags positive variances.

value: Stocks are well controlled, we shall confirm the polybags unit weight to establish if we have the correct weight per piece.

•    We shall investigate polybags bundles to establish whether we receive as per quantity indicated.
•    The rest of the stock items are well controlled.

•    In prior audit, the following were the stock findings;
    Bread -     -35.25 loaves.
    Cumulative variance in polybags was -271 pieces.
    All other materials had negligible variances.

•    Stock take was conducted on 27th May 2025 to establish whether the physical stocks were matching with the stock book balance generated from SAP system and whether internal controls on stocks were effective.
Apart from positive variance in polybags, the rest of the stocks items were found to be well controlled.
Operations/Production Department
To examine whether the physical stocks were matching with the stock book balance generated from SAP system and whether internal controls on stocks were effective.

attributes.title: Bread Weight Check
attributes.description: From the samples picked, bread weight check across various varieties was as Illustrated below;
attributes.recommendation:
•    The branch management should maintain production weight controls in place.
•    Overweight cases should also be checked to ensure the branch yield is not compromised.
attributes.effect:
•    The company is at risk of incurring penalties if underweight bread is detected in the market by Weights and Measures officials.
•    Supplying underweight bread can lead to consumer dissatisfaction.

value: •    Overcooling is the major cause of underweights noted, especially on the 600g variety whose production is low. We will improve on this.
•    Regular random checks on the cooling wires and at the dividing table to ensure we maintain the set standards.
•    In prior audit, underweight were picked across all varieties as follows; 400g SN – 1.33%, 400g W – 0%, 600g W – 8%, 800g W – 8% and 1.5kg W – 14.67%.

Bread weight check was done by selecting a sample from packed bread ready to be dispatched to the market. The aim was to establish whether the bread dispatched to the market meets the required weight standards.
There were prevalent cases of underweight noted, except for 400g CT, 600g CT & 400g Brown which had 20%, 25% & 16% respectively and require close monitoring.
Operations/Production Department
To ensure that finished products dispatched to the market meets the required weight standard.

attributes.title: Damages Analysis
attributes.description:
•    It was noted that production damages were averaging at 0.25% of the total production and market damages stood at 0.41% of the total sales. 
•    Physical verification of damages over the same period revealed a variation of -32.9 kgs equivalent to 82.9 loaves.
attributes.recommendation: •    The branch management should emphasis on controlling Production damages to the acceptable level of 0.2% to the total production.
attributes.effect: Production damages recorded for the period exceeded the acceptable level of 0.2%. This resulted to revenue forfeiture of Kshs. 31,203.75

value: •    We recently introduced new tins in rotation, this has contributed to increase in production damages level otherwise this should come down with time.
•    The overall damages level of 0.66% were within the cumulative allowable level of 0.70%, However, the branch should work to keep production damages at the set level of 0.2%

•    In the previous audit, Production damages for 1st to 28th Feb was at 0.257%, while market damages for the same period was at 0.34% for the same period, Production damages for the period 1st march to 17th March was at 0.255% and market damages was at 0.37% for the same period.

•    Analysis of production and market damages was done for a period of 34 days from 23rd April 2025 to 26th May 2025 to determine whether production and market damages were within the desired percentages of 0.20% of the total production and 0.50% of the total sales respectively.
Production damages were above the acceptable rate by 0.05% which implies the company lost revenue of Kshs. 31,203.75. Market Damages were within the acceptable rate.
Operations/Production Department
To determine whether production and market damages were within the desired rates of 0.20% of the total production and 0.50% of the total sales respectively.

attributes.title: Mixing Charts Analysis
attributes.description:
•    Below is a summary of physical mixing charts data compared to SAP  production for the period;

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

•   It was noted that, Average production was 180.29 bags per day, which is 89% of the daily target of 202.5 bags. Yield achieved during the period was 192.08. 
•    The table below shows summarized findings of the mixing chart production analysis.
attributes.recommendation: •    Branch should continue to adhere with production standards and also take advantage of the available production capacity whenever there is need to.

value: •    Production scheduling contributed to target shortfall.
•    Production target shortfall result from shift cuts. We have one deck in the branch that remains closed as we manage production as per bread demand.

•    In the previous audit, there was no significant variance between system and the actual material consumption.
•    Correct posting was also noted over the audited period.

•    An analysis of mixing chart summaries was done for a period of 34 days from 23rd April 2025 to 26th May 2025, to confirm production data accuracy from mixing charts to cash flow and SAP. Raw materials usage as per the set BOM, production yield and if the set production standards were achieved.

•    Production capacity available is not fully utilized with 11% idle capacity.
•    The branch average yield achieved for the period was within the standards.
•    Material usage was as per the BOM and data from the physical mixing charts to SAP was found to be accurate.
Operations/Production Department
To confirm production data accuracy from mixing charts to cash flow and SAP. Raw materials usage as per the set BOM, production yield and if the set production standards were achieved.

attributes.title: Cash Verification
attributes.description:
•    Cash counted compared to cash flow balance had Kshs +4 variance 
•    There were 7 pending IOU’s amounting to Kshs. 41,350 as illustrated below.
attributes.recommendation:
•    The branch cashier should maintain the cash controls in place.
•    Clearance of outstanding IOUs should be expedited.
attributes.effect: Minimal cash variation is an indication of good controls in place

value: •    This is noted.
•    The November 2024 outstanding IOU shall be cleared in due cause
•    In the previous audit, Minimal variances were noted during spot-check.

•    Verification of cash held at the cash office was done on 28th May 2025, to confirm whether cash held by the cashier matches the expected cash and whether the set cash operation standards are adhered to.

There was minimal cash variance which implies that adequate cash controls are in place.

There is violation of company timelines on IOUs clearance.
Finance Department
To confirm the cash held by the cashier matches the expected cash and whether the set cash operation standards are adhered to.

attributes.title: Mini shop Spot Check
attributes.description: •    Mini shop attendant accounted for bread loaded as well as sales proceeds as illustrated below.
attributes.recommendation: •    The controls in place at the mini shop were found to be adequate.
attributes.effect: The standard operating procedures were being observed as noted and the company is not exposed.

value: •    Mini-shop operations shall be maintained by ensuring that the attendant observe the set standards.
•    As operation team, we shall ensure that the mini-shop operates within the confines of the set standards.
•    In the prior audit, the shop attendant accounted for all the bread loaded.
•    A spot check was conducted in the mini shop on 27th May 2025 to assess whether the operation were being carried out in accordance with the established standards.
The shop is being managed properly
Sales Department
Bread is sold on cash, No bread at the shop which is not documented for & all sales proceeds are properly accounted for.

attributes.title: Production Efficiency
attributes.description:
•    It was noted that the production efficiency for the period was 4.57 bags per production worker. 

A summary of production analysis is shown below;
attributes.recommendation: •    The controls in place on production workers are adequate, commendable and this should be maintained.
attributes.effect: Production efficiency of 4.57 bags per worker implies that the employed production labour was well controlled and the company did not incur unbudgeted production labour costs.

value: •    We shall maintain.
•    Workers are properly managed and we shall continue to ensure this is maintained.

•    In the prior audit, Production efficiency for 1st Feb to 28th Feb was 4.62 bags per production worker, while production efficiency from 1st March to 17th March was 4.63 bags per production worker.

Production efficiency was calculated for period of 34 days from 23rd April 2025 to 26th May 2025. The aim was to determine if the production workers hired achieved the set production efficiency of 4.5 bags per worker.
The company set efficiency level was achieved a demonstration of adequate controls on production workers hired.
Operations/Production Department
To ensure production workers achieve the set company output standard of 4.5bags per production worker hired.

attributes.title: Packing Efficiency
attributes.description:
Analysis revealed that the average slicing efficiency for the period was 95.61 crates per slicer. 

The table below illustrates the findings;-
attributes.recommendation: Branch management should ensure hiring of packers is well controlled to eliminate any form of inefficiency.
attributes.effect: At 95.61 crates per slicer, the 97 standard was slightly missed which implies that the branch hired 12 extra slicer at a cost of Kshs 10,944 for the 34 day period.

value: The slight miss on efficiency is noted and we shall check to eliminate the inefficiency.
The efficiency is fairly good though with s slight miss on the expected efficiency. We will push our packers to operate within the standards.
In the prior audit, slicing efficiency from 1st Feb to 28th Feb was 96.76 crates per slicer while efficiency from 1st March to 17th March was 96.55 crates per slicer.
Slicing efficiency was calculated over a 34-days period, from 23rd April 2025 to 26th May 2025, to determine whether the KPI of 97 crates per slicer was being met.
The packing KPI of 97 crates per packers was slightly missed and Kshs. 10944 were incurred over and above the budgeted labour costs.
Operations/Production Department
To ensure the company set standards of 97 crates per slicer hired is being met.

attributes.title: Motor Vehicle Fuel Consumption
attributes.description:
•    It was noted that apart from KCA 853A, KBZ 513T & KCG 201S which slightly consumed more than expected, the rest of branch motor vehicles were saving as compared to the set standards.
•    It was also noted KCG 201S - Reliever Vehicle had rampant faulty odometer reading 

Motor vehicle consumption analysis table
attributes.recommendation:
•    Fuel consumption controls should be maintained.
•    The case of faulty odometer on Motor vehicle KCG 201S requires attention.
attributes.effect:
•    Fleet Minimal consumption variations from the set standards is an indication of efficient fuel management.
•    Faulty odometer on KCG 201S will not provide accurate data for decision making.

value: •    We shall continue to monitor vehicle consumption to ensure they are within the set standards
•    The controls on fuel consumption shall be maintained.
•    In the prior audit, it was noted that there was economical fuel consumption by the sales vans.
•    Motor vehicle fuel consumption analysis was done for the period 1st May 2025 to 27th May 2025, to evaluate compliance with set fuel standard for each vehicle.
Minimal variations in vehicle consumption rates as compared to the set standards is an indication of good control.
Transport/Fleet Department
To evaluate compliance with set fuel standard for each vehicle
